title: Non-Drug Interventions for Treating Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD)
author: WebMD Editorial Contributors

content: Non-drug interventions for ADHD include making adjustments in the environment to promote more successful social interactions. Such adjustments include creating more structure and encouraging routines.

sections.heading: Treatments for Children with ADHD
content: Children with ADHD may need help in organizing their lives. Therefore, some simple interventions to try for childhood ADHD include:

The FDA has also approved a digital therapy device called EndeavorRx which has been shown to help treat children ages 8 to 12 years old with ADHD. Using a video game approach, the device gives the child motor skill challenges and helps stimulate areas of the brain to help improve brain function.
Note that children with ADHD need consistent rules that they can easily follow. When your child follows rules, they should be rewarded.
bullets: Create a schedule. Make sure your child has the same routine every day. The schedule should include homework time and playtime. Post this schedule in a prominent place in the home.
Help your child organize everyday items. Work with your child to have a place for everything. This includes clothing, backpacks, and school supplies.

sections.heading: Treatments for Adult ADHD
content: Adult ADHD may be treated with one or more of the following:
bullets: Individual cognitive and behavioral therapy to change negative thought patterns and enhance self-esteem
Relaxation training and stress management to reduce anxiety and stress
Behavioral coaching to teach strategies for organizing home and work activities
Job coaching or mentoring to support better working relationships and improve on-the-job performance
